elements.content: In this paper, seven new compounds [Cu(biim-4)2(L1)2] (1), [Cu(biim-4)2(L2)2] (2), [Cu(biim-4)2(H2O)](L3)2·H2O (3), [Cu(L4)2](H2biim-4)·8H2O (4), [Cu(biim-4)1.5(H2O)3](L5)·2H2O (5), [Cu(biim-6)3](L1)2 (6), and [Cu(biim-6)3](L2)2·H2O (7), where HL1 = 3-amino-4-methylbenzenesulfonic acid, HL2 = 2-amino-3,5-dimethylbenzenesulfonic acid, HL3 = 4-amino-2,5-dichlorobenzenesulfonic acid, H2L4 = 8-hydroxyquinoline-5-sulfonic acid, H2L5 = 1,5-naphthenedisulfonic acid, biim-4 = 1,1′-(1,4-butanediyl)bis(imidazole), and biim-6 = 1,1′-(1,6-hexanediyl)bis(imidazole), were successfully synthesized. The sulfonate anions of compounds 1, 2, and 4 coordinate to copper ions, while the sulfonates of 3 and 5–7 only act as counterions. In compounds 1–3, 6, and 7, copper ions are bridged by biim-4 or biim-6 ligands to form two-dimensional (2D) polymeric networks; in compound 5, copper ions are bridged by biim-4 ligands to form a one-dimensional (1D) ladder structure. In 4, [Cu(L4)2]2– anions, [H2biim-4]2+ cations and lattice–water molecules are linked through hydrogen bonds and π−π interactions to give a three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular framework.
elements.clean_text: In this paper, seven new compounds [Cu(biim-4)2(L1)2] (1), [Cu(biim-4)2(L2)2] (2), [Cu(biim-4)2(H2O)](L3)2⋅H2O (3), [Cu(L4)2](H2biim-4)⋅8H2O (4), [Cu(biim-4)1.5(H2O)3](L5)⋅2H2O (5), [Cu(biim-6)3](L1)2 (6), and [Cu(biim-6)3](L2)2⋅H2O (7), where HL1 = 3-amino-4-methylbenzenesulfonic acid, HL2 = 2-amino-3,5-dimethylbenzenesulfonic acid, HL3 = 4-amino-2,5-dichlorobenzenesulfonic acid, H2L4 = 8-hydroxyquinoline-5-sulfonic acid, H2L5 = 1,5-naphthenedisulfonic acid, biim-4 = 1,1'-(1,4-butanediyl)bis(imidazole), and biim-6 = 1,1'-(1,6-hexanediyl)bis(imidazole), were successfully synthesized. The sulfonate anions of compounds 1, 2, and 4 coordinate to copper ions, while the sulfonates of 3 and 5-7 only act as counterions. In compounds 1-3, 6, and 7, copper ions are bridged by biim-4 or biim-6 ligands to form two-dimensional (2D) polymeric networks; in compound 5, copper ions are bridged by biim-4 ligands to form a one-dimensional (1D) ladder structure. In 4, [Cu(L4)2]2- anions, [H2biim-4]2+ cations and lattice-water molecules are linked through hydrogen bonds and π-π interactions to give a three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular framework.

elements.content:
Seven new Cu(II)-bis(imidazole) compounds were successfully synthesized. They form two-dimensional and three-dimensional networks that may be finely tuned by using different sulfonate anions.

Introduction

The self-assembly of metal−organic coordination polymers is attracting great attention because of their potential as functional materials and their intriguing structural frameworks. The coordination polymers can be designed on the basis of the interaction of metal ions with bridging organic ligands. For instance, gridlike layers can be obtained by assembling linear spacers with metal ions either preferring a square-planar geometry or displaying an octahedron. In the self-assembly processes, many factors influence the formation of the final architectures, such as the solvent system, template, central metal, and anion. Generally, the fine changes of ligands may lead to different structures. If the coordination interaction between metal ion and ligand is very strong, the fine change of the ligands may result in a greatly different framework. On the other hand, if the coordination interaction between metal ion and ligand is very weak, the resulting metal−organic framework should be labile, and it is also difficult to realize the fine-tuning of the framework. Imidazole-containing ligands, such as 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene, 1,1′-(1,4-butanediyl)bis(imidazole), 1,3,5-tris-(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene, and related species, represent a class of aromatic N-donor organic linkers. According to previous reports, these N-containing ligands tend to form strong coordination bonds to copper ions. It is also well-known that sulfonate anions are generally considered to be weakly interacting or noninteracting to transition metal ions and that they even cannot efficiently displace water from the primary coordination sphere. In this study, copper ion, an aromatic N-containing ligand, and sulfonate anion are selected as the ternary reactants. Since coordination between copper ion and sulfonate anion is very weak, the change of sulfonate anions may finely tune the framework.

Generally, the fine changes of ligands may lead to different structures. If the coordination interaction between metal ion and ligand is very strong, the fine change of the ligands may result in a greatly different framework. On the other hand, if the coordination interaction between metal ion and ligand is very weak, the resulting metal-organic framework should be labile, and it is also difficult to realize the fine-tuning of the framework. elements.content:
All reagents and solvents for syntheses were purchased from commercial sources and used as received. biim-4 and biim-6 were synthesized in accordance with the reported procedure.

Synthesis of Compound <bold>1</bold>

After a mixture of CuCl2·2H2O (0.171 g, 1 mmol), NaOH (0.080 g, 2 mmol) in water (10 mL) was stirred for 10 min at room temperature, the Cu(OH)2 solid was collected by filtration and washed with water. HL1 (0.374 g, 2 mmol) was added to the Cu(OH)2 suspension in water (10 mL) with stirring. After biim-4 (0.380 g, 2 mmol) was added, a blue precipitate was obtained. A minimum amount of ammonia (14 M) was added to give a blue solution. Suitable crystals were obtained after standing at room temperature for several days. The crystals were collected, washed with water, and dried in air.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

All reagents and solvents for syntheses were purchased from commercial sources and used as received. biim-4 and biim-6 were synthesized in accordance with the reported procedure. 

Synthesis of Compound 1 

After a mixture of CuCl2⋅2H2O (0.171 g, 1 mmol), NaOH (0.080 g, 2 mmol) in water (10 mL) was stirred for 10 min at room temperature, the Cu(OH)2 solid was collected by filtration and washed with water. HL1 (0.374 g, 2 mmol) was added to the Cu(OH)2 suspension in water (10 mL) with stirring. After biim-4 (0.380 g, 2 mmol) was added, a blue precipitate was obtained. A minimum amount of ammonia (14 M) was added to give a blue solution. Suitable crystals were obtained after standing at room temperature for several days. The crystals were collected, washed with water, and dried in air.

elements.content:
Compounds 2–7 were prepared similarly to compound 1. Yield and elemental analysis of compounds 1–7 are listed in . The FT-IR spectra analysis of compounds 1–7 are listed in .

General Characterization and Physical Measurements

The C, H, and N elemental analysis was conducted on a Perkin-Elmer 240 elemental analyzer. The FT-IR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range 4000–400 cm−1 on a Mattson Alpha-Centauri spectrometer. TGA was performed on a Perkin-Elmer TG-7 analyzer heated from room temperature to 600 °C under nitrogen.

elements.content: X-ray diffraction data for compounds 1 and 6 were recorded on a Bruker Apex CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293 K. Crystallographic data for compounds 2–5 and 7 were collected on a Rigaku RAXIS-RAPID single-crystal diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293 K. Absorption corrections were applied using a multiscan technique. All the structures were solved by Direct Method of SHELXS-97 and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques using the SHELXL-97 program within WINGX. Nonhydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic temperature parameters. The hydrogen atoms attached to carbons were generated geometrically; the aqua and amino hydrogen atoms were located from difference Fourier maps and refined with isotropic displacement parameters. Analytical expressions of neutral-atom scattering factors were employed, and anomalous dispersion corrections were incorporated. Detailed crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters for 1–7 are summarized in Table .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

X-ray diffraction data for compounds 1 and 6 were recorded on a Bruker Apex CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293 K. Crystallographic data for compounds 2-5 and 7 were collected on a Rigaku RAXIS-RAPID single-crystal diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293 K. Absorption corrections were applied using a multiscan technique. All the structures were solved by Direct Method of SHELXS-97 and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques using the SHELXL-97 program within WINGX. Nonhydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic temperature parameters. The hydrogen atoms attached to carbons were generated geometrically; the aqua and amino hydrogen atoms were located from difference Fourier maps and refined with isotropic displacement parameters. Analytical expressions of neutral-atom scattering factors were employed, and anomalous dispersion corrections were incorporated. Detailed crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters for 1-7 are summarized in Table .

elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

Since compounds 1-7 are insoluble in water and common organic solvents, the crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis cannot be obtained by evaporating an appropriate solution of them. It is found that they can be dissolved in a concentrated solution of ammonia. So the crystals of compounds 1-7 were obtained by evaporating an ammonia solution of them.

elements.content: Selected bond distances and angles for compounds 1–7 are listed in . As shown in Figure a, the Cu(II) cation in 1 is octahedrally coordinated by four nitrogen atoms from four biim-4 ligands and two O atoms from two sulfonate anions. The Cu−N distances range from 1.980(2) to 2.030(2) Å, which are similar to the reported distances. Owing to the Jahn–Teller effect, the Cu−O distances of 2.598(3) and 2.604(3) Å are much longer than the average values. Cu(II) cations are bridged by biim-4 ligands to give a two-dimensional (2D) grid layer (Figure b). All of three kinds of crystallographically independent biim-4 ligands adopt “S” shaped conformations (Scheme a). In addition, hydrogen-bond interaction exists between the amino group and the oxygen atom from another sulfonate anion ().

Cu(II) cations are bridged by biim-4 ligands to give a two-dimensional (2D) grid layer (Figure b). elements.content: In compound 2, the Cu(II) cation shows a slightly distorted octahedral geometry with two O atoms from two sulfonate anions in the axial positions and four N atoms from four biim-4 molecules in the equatorial positions (Figure a). The Cu−N distances range from 2.013(2) to 2.019(2) Å. The Cu−O distance of 2.444(2) Å is longer than the general Cu−O distances. The biim-4 ligands take the “Ω” conformations (Scheme b), which connect Cu(II) cations to give a 2D grid layer (Figure b).
elements.clean_text: In compound 2, the Cu(II) cation shows a slightly distorted octahedral geometry with two O atoms from two sulfonate anions in the axial positions and four N atoms from four biim-4 molecules in the equatorial positions (Figure a). The Cu-N distances range from 2.013(2) to 2.019(2) Å. The Cu-O distance of 2.444(2) Å is longer than the general Cu-O distances. The biim-4 ligands take the "Ω" conformations (Scheme b), which connect Cu(II) cations to give a 2D grid layer (Figure b).

elements.content: As shown in Figure a, the Cu(II) cation in 3 has a square pyramidal coordination geometry with four N atoms from four biim-4 molecules in the basal positions and a water molecule in the apical one. The water molecule at another axial site (Cu−O2W 2.799(3) Å) has a weak interaction with the Cu(II) cation. Three kinds of biim-4 ligands display zigzag conformations (Scheme c), while another kind of biim-4 ligand adopts an “S” conformation (Scheme a). Cu(II) ions are bridged by biim-4 ligands to give a 2D polymeric layer (Figure b), with the sulfonate anions acting as counterions. The coordinated and lattice–water molecules offer hydrogen atoms to form hydrogen bonds with oxygen atoms of sulfonate anions (Figure c). π−π interactions exist (face-to-face distance of 3.48 Å, Figure c) between the adjacent sulfonate anions. The 2D layers are connected by hydrogen bonds and π−π interactions to result in a three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular framework.

elements.content: According to a previous report, coordination networks made from long bridging ligands can give rise to the formation of large voids as well as interpenetrating motifs. In this compound, a closer examination of a packing diagram without sulfonate anions and water molecules reveals the presence of channels along the a axis with an effective rectangular window size of 3.34 × 6.68 Å2 ().

elements.content: As shown in Figure a, Cu(II) cation in 4 is coordinated by a pair of chelating L4 anions to furnish a square-planar coordination geometry. The metal ion lies in the plane formed by two N atoms and two O atoms. The weak interaction between the Cu(II) ion and oxygen atom of sulfonate anion (Cu−O3#1 2.714(2) Å) extends the [Cu(L4)2]2− anions to a one-dimensional (1D) supramolecular chain. π−π interactions also exist between the aromatic rings of adjacent sulfonate anions (face-to-face distance of 3.65 Å, ), which help to further fasten the chain.
elements.clean_text: As shown in Figure a, Cu(II) cation in 4 is coordinated by a pair of chelating L4 anions to furnish a square-planar coordination geometry. The metal ion lies in the plane formed by two N atoms and two O atoms. The weak interaction between the Cu(II) ion and oxygen atom of sulfonate anion (Cu-O3#1 2.714(2) Å) extends the [Cu(L4)2]2- anions to a one-dimensional (1D) supramolecular chain. π-π interactions also exist between the aromatic rings of adjacent sulfonate anions (face-to-face distance of 3.65 Å, ), which help to further fasten the chain.

elements.content: In compound 4, the biim-4 is protonated. The [H2biim-4]2+ cation connects with L4 anion through face-to-face π−π interactions (face-to-face distance of 3.45 Å Figure b). In addition, hydrogen bonds exist between water molecules, [H2biim-4]2+ cations and sulfonate anions. As a result, a 3D supramolecular framework is constructed by these noncovalent interactions.

elements.content: As shown in Figure a, Cu(II) cation in 5 is six-coordinated by three N atoms from three biim-4 ligands and three water molecules. The Cu−N distances range from 2.007(2) to 2.021(2) Å. The Cu−O distances in the axial positions are much longer than the distance in the equatorial position. Cu(II) ions are bridged by biim-4 molecules to form a 1D ladder-like structure (Figure b).

elements.content: In 5, uncoordinated sulfonate anions and water molecules are linked through hydrogen bonds to form a 2D supramolecular layer (Figure c). Both coordinated water molecules (O1W, O2W, and O5W) and lattice–water molecules (O3W and O4W) exist in 5. As shown in Figure d, O2W acts as a donor and donates hydrogen bonds to two sulfonate oxygen atoms. O4W donates hydrogen bonds to O1W#3 (symmetry code: #3 x + 1, y, z) and O3W, which in turn donate to sulfonate oxygen atoms. O1W and O3W behave as both acceptors and donors, while O4W behaves as a donor only. The whole structure of 5 is connected by hydrogen bonds to result in a 3D supramolecular framework.

elements.content: To further investigate the fine-tuning of the frameworks constructed by Cu(II) ion and biim-6 ligand, the structures of 6 and 7 have been determined. As shown in Figure a, the Cu(II) cation in 6 shows a slightly distorted octahedral geometry completed by the coordination of six N atoms from six biim-6 ligands. The distances of four Cu−N bonds in the equatorial positions are similar to the reported distances, while the Cu−N distances corresponding to the axial N atoms are much longer than the normal distances. Cu(II) ions are bridged by biim-6 ligands to form two kinds of polymeric chains (single- and double-stranded), which intersect each other to form a 2D polymeric structure (Figure b). In the structure of 6, some channels exist that are mainly occupied by sulfonate anions ().

elements.content: Although compounds 1–3 contain different sulfonate anions, they possess similiar 2D (4,4) networks constructed by Cu(II) ions and biim-4 ligands. Different sulfonate anions can finely tune the networks through changing the conformations of biim-4 ligands.
elements.clean_text:
The Fine-Tuning of the Cu(II)-bis(imidazole) Networks through Changing Sulfonate Anions

Although compounds 1-3 contain different sulfonate anions, they possess similiar 2D (4,4) networks constructed by Cu(II) ions and biim-4 ligands. Different sulfonate anions can finely tune the networks through changing the conformations of biim-4 ligands.

elements.content: As shown in Scheme , the flexible biim-4 ligand may display different conformations: the “S” conformation (Scheme a), the “Ω” conformation (Scheme b), and the zigzag conformation (Scheme c). In compound 1, when L1 was employed, biim-4 adopted an “S” conformation (with Cu···Cu separations from 11.25 to 11.27 Å), but when L2 was employed in 2, biim-4 adopted an “Ω” conformation (with Cu···Cu separation of 10.29 Å). In compound 3, biim-4 ligands adopt the zigzag (with Cu···Cu separations from 12.82 to 13.91 Å) and “S” (with Cu···Cu separation of 11.93 Å) conformations. It is obvious that different conformations can lead to different lengths of the biim-4, which results in grids with different lengths and angles. When the “Ω” conformation was adopted in compound 2, the Cu···Cu separation across the biim-4 ligand was shorter than that of the other two conformations, which may prevent the formation of the channel structure. In compound 3, most of the ligands adopt the zigzag conformations, which offer wide space for the formation of the channels.
elements.clean_text: As shown in Scheme , the flexible biim-4 ligand may display different conformations: the "S" conformation (Scheme a), the "Ω" conformation (Scheme b), and the zigzag conformation (Scheme c). In compound 1, when L1 was employed, biim-4 adopted an "S" conformation (with Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu separations from 11.25 to 11.27 Å), but when L2 was employed in 2, biim-4 adopted an "Ω" conformation (with Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu separation of 10.29 Å). In compound 3, biim-4 ligands adopt the zigzag (with Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu separations from 12.82 to 13.91 Å) and "S" (with Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu separation of 11.93 Å) conformations. It is obvious that different conformations can lead to different lengths of the biim-4, which results in grids with different lengths and angles. When the "Ω" conformation was adopted in compound 2, the Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu separation across the biim-4 ligand was shorter than that of the other two conformations, which may prevent the formation of the channel structure. In compound 3, most of the ligands adopt the zigzag conformations, which offer wide space for the formation of the channels.

elements.content: Since sulfonate anions show weak coordination interaction to the Cu(II) ion, they may tune the Cu(II)-(biim-4) networks through weak interactions: (1) Coordination interaction. In 1 and 2, L1 and L2 are weakly coordinated to Cu(II) ions, while in 3 L3 is uncoordinated. In 1, there exist hydrogen-bonding interactions between L1 anions, while L2 in 2 shows no hydrogen-bonding interactions. For 3, complicated hydrogen-bonding interactions exist between the L3 anion and water molecules. According to previous reports, sulfonate anions are good hydrogen-bond acceptors and can form strong hydrogen bonds with hydrogen donors. The uncoordination of L3 anion in 3 may be due to the hydrogen-bonding interactions (Figure c). (2) π−π interactions. In 3, π−π interactions exist between L3 anions, while there are no π−π interactions for 1 and 2. (3) Packing interaction. Since the numbers, positions, and types of substituent groups are different from each other, L1, L2, and L3 have different shapes that show different packing requirements.

Since the numbers, positions, and types of substituent groups are different from each other, L1, L2, and L3 have different shapes that show different packing requirements.

elements.content: Although L1, L2, and L3 may finely tune the Cu(II)-(biim-4) networks of 1–3, drastic changes in the sulfonate ions may result in completely different frameworks. Since L4 and L5 are much different from L1, L2, and L3, 4 and 5 show greatly different structures. The N and O atoms of L4 anion may adopt a chelating mode that has a much stronger coordination ability to the Cu(II) ion than the sulfonate group. In compound 4, each Cu(II) ion is coordinated by two chelating L4 anions to form a discrete [Cu(L4)2]2− anion, and biim-4 ligands act only as protonated counterions [H2biim-4]2+. L5 anion contains two sulfonate groups while L1, L2, and L3 are all monosulfonate anions, and compound 5 shows a 1D ladder structure rather than the 2D polymeric networks of 1, 2, and 3.

L5 anion contains two sulfonate groups while L1, L2, and L3 are all monosulfonate anions, and compound 5 shows a 1D ladder structure rather than the 2D polymeric networks of 1, 2, and 3.

elements.content: Because of the strong coordination ability of the imidazole group to Cu(II) ion, the structures of 6 and 7 are completely different from the structures of the corresponding compounds 1 and 2 even if the structural difference between biim-6 and biim-4 are very small. Although 6 and 7 contain different sulfonate anions (L1 and L2), they show similar Cu(II)-(biim-6) networks that are also finely tuned by sulfonate anions.

Although 6 and 7 contain different sulfonate anions (L1 and L2), they show similar Cu(II)-(biim-6) networks that are also finely tuned by sulfonate anions.

elements.content: From the above discussion, it can be seen that the Cu(II)-bis(imidazole) networks can be finely tuned by changing sulfonate anions. The slight differences of networks can result in some changes of the properties of the networks. For example, the network of 7 can capture one lattice–water molecule per unit cell, while no water molecules exist in the structure of 6.

elements.content: To characterize the compounds more fully in terms of thermal stability, some thermal behaviors were studied by TGA (). The experiments were performed on samples consisting of numerous single crystals of 3–7 under N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C/min.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Analysis

To characterize the compounds more fully in terms of thermal stability, some thermal behaviors were studied by TGA (). The experiments were performed on samples consisting of numerous single crystals of 3-7 under N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C/min.

elements.content: For compound 3, the weight loss corresponding to the release of water molecules are observed from 115 to 150 °C (obsd 4.1%, calcd 3.74%). The lattice–water molecule is much more difficult to remove due to the hydrogen-bonding interactions. The anhydrous compound begins to decompose at 252 °C. For compound 4, the weight loss attributed to the gradual release of water molecules is observed in the range 30–70 °C (a weight loss of 5.1% is smaller than the calculated value 17.03% probably resulting from a slow loss of the guest molecules at room temperature). The anhydrous compound begins to decompose at 270 °C. The TGA curve of 5 shows that it undergoes dehydration in two steps in the temperature range of 54–117 °C (obsd 7.08%, calcd 7.46%) and 117–232 °C (obsd 5.02%, calcd 4.98%) per formula unit. The first step corresponds to the loss of two lattices and one coordinated water molecules. This phenomenon can be understood because of the presence of hydrogen-bonding interactions between the lattice and coordinate water molecules; the second step corresponds to the loss of another two coordinated water molecules. The anhydrous compound begins to decompose at 300 °C. Compound 6 begins to decompose at 230 °C. For compound 7, the weight loss attributed to the gradual release of water molecules is hardly observed (probably resulting from a slow loss of the guest molecules at room temperature.). The anhydrous compound begins to compose at 225 °C.

elements.content: Seven different Cu(II) coordination compounds with five sulfonate anions and two bis(imidazole) ligands have been prepared and structurally characterized. The results of this study not only demonstrate that sulfonate anions and the conformation of the bis(imidazole) ligands may tune the frameworks of metal−organic polymers but also illustrate that hydrogen bonds and π−π interactions may also play an important role in the formation of final constructions.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Seven different Cu(II) coordination compounds with five sulfonate anions and two bis(imidazole) ligands have been prepared and structurally characterized. The results of this study not only demonstrate that sulfonate anions and the conformation of the bis(imidazole) ligands may tune the frameworks of metal-organic polymers but also illustrate that hydrogen bonds and π-π interactions may also play an important role in the formation of final constructions.

elements.content: Seven X-ray crystallographic files (CIF). Selected bond distances and angles. Hydrogen bonds between two L1 anions in compound 1. Packing diagram for compounds 3, 6, and 7. 1D supramolecular chain in compound 4. TGA curves of compounds 3–7. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

cln_elements.content:
All reagents and solvents for syntheses were purchased from commercial sources and used as received. biim-4 and biim-6 were synthesized in accordance with the reported procedure.

Synthesis of Compound <bold>1</bold>

After a mixture of CuCl2·2H2O (0.171 g, 1 mmol), NaOH (0.080 g, 2 mmol) in water (10 mL) was stirred for 10 min at room temperature, the Cu(OH)2 solid was collected by filtration and washed with water. HL1 (0.374 g, 2 mmol) was added to the Cu(OH)2 suspension in water (10 mL) with stirring. After biim-4 (0.380 g, 2 mmol) was added, a blue precipitate was obtained. A minimum amount of ammonia (14 M) was added to give a blue solution. Suitable crystals were obtained after standing at room temperature for several days. The crystals were collected, washed with water, and dried in air.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

All reagents and solvents for syntheses were purchased from commercial sources and used as received. biim-4 and biim-6 were synthesized in accordance with the reported procedure. 

Synthesis of Compound 1 

After a mixture of CuCl2⋅2H2O (0.171 g, 1 mmol), NaOH (0.080 g, 2 mmol) in water (10 mL) was stirred for 10 min at room temperature, the Cu(OH)2 solid was collected by filtration and washed with water. HL1 (0.374 g, 2 mmol) was added to the Cu(OH)2 suspension in water (10 mL) with stirring. After biim-4 (0.380 g, 2 mmol) was added, a blue precipitate was obtained. A minimum amount of ammonia (14 M) was added to give a blue solution. Suitable crystals were obtained after standing at room temperature for several days. The crystals were collected, washed with water, and dried in air.
